Title: Final assignment: number of bars
Post_text: I know mine is short enough. I can'tÂ possibly use all the things we learned in such a short piece. I looked up binary form and I found an example by Mozart (sonata in A major) and it is very short also only about 20 or so measures counting the repeated bars. Hi Peter, Firstly, thanks for a very interesting and useful course. Secondly,Â  I have a question about the final assignment: What do you mean by 20-30bars?Â  Is that the number of written bars or the number of barsto be played?Â  For example, if I have 4 bars which end with a repeat sign doesthat count as 4 bars or 8 bars? if I have 5 bars where the fourth bar is a firsttime ending and the fifth bar is a second time ending is that 5 bars or 9 bars? Once again, thanks for a great course, Ed I have the same question. I don't know. I know when I listen to it on playback those repeated measures are played back again and it "sounds" extra bars. Maybe in the next lecture Dr. Edwards will clarify. Same question from me, Adding three cadences to 30 bars really breaks the melodic component. Â It will be much nicer if we can have 30 bars of written music with a repeated part ending in a H.C. and D.C. before concluding in a PAC. Â  To fit in all the elements asked for in the final assignment within 20-30 bars will be hard enough. I would not cut it down to 10-15 by counting the repeats. Title: my solution to assign 4
Post_text:
#URLREF   If anyone can comment on this I would much appreciate it.Â  I have a simpler harmony after the Dec cadence partly to save time but also I think it makes a nice effect .  I don't much like the overall result though!    
I think some of your note choices could be improved in the second phrase. For example, in bar 6 an F natural would sound better to my ear than the F sharp. In bar 8, you have a B flat in the oboe and a B natural in the piano chord, which I don't think is stylistically acceptable. Also in bar 8, I don't understand the chord on the second beat - I think a G in the left hand would be better that the D, which doesn't belong to the chord if it's meant to be C minor (i). Those are the main things that jump out at me.  Is your DC at bars 10-11? It doesn't really sound like a cadence, because the music doesn't stop at all.

HI Matija! Thanks for sharing. Getting to critique your assignment helps me learn this stuff, too!  This might not be complete, but this is what I noticed:  1. In measure one, you have the alto part sing an F on the second chord. Since this chord is listed as V64, it is not a seventh chord and so there would be no F included here.  2. In the second chord of measure 2, you have doubled the fifth. This tends to leave a "hollower" sound for a chord in root position, and it would be preferable to double the root.  3. In measure 4, you have the tenor on E and the alto on G, when this chord is actually provided by the assignment with the tenor singing G and the alto E (like your next chord).  4. In measure 6, second chord, you've doubled the third; doubling the root again would be preferable  5. in measure 7, you have the bass go up an octave. While it could be a fine decision in itself, you stay up in that register for a little while, setting up a very awkward (and perhaps unorthodox?) leap of a ninth in between measures 8 and 9.  6. Finally, I challenge you to write this using four separate voices (i.e., one stem for soprano, alto, tenor and bass). You seem to have this in measure 12 on the last chord. Title: Prallel octaves/fifths vs. sonority. How strict is the rule?
Post_text:
The question is: should I eliminate parallel octaves/fifths at the cost of breaking sonority? How strict is this rule?  A similar question: should I manage appropriate distance between alto and tenor at the cost of sonority?  #MATH  
 It would be helpful if you define what do you mean by sonority in this case :)  To expand a bit on a comment I wrote in that thread:     Remember that's it's a four part writing, not a piano piece.Â   A piano playing in octaves or fifths gives certain richness to the sound which may be perfectly fine if that's the effect you're going for.Â  However it will not be two separate voices that happen to stay an octave apart, it would sound at best as a single voice that "plays octaves".      So when there are parallel perfect intervals between voices that otherwise move independently, it's as if they're suddenly merged intoÂ  a single voice and then separate again after the parallels end. It may not be apparent when the chords are played by piano, but if each voice is actuallyÂ   a separate instrument, the sense of emptiness produced by parallels is much more pronounced.  
 It's worth bearing in mind the actual sonic character of parallel fifths/octaves (for which "emptiness" is a good description, I think). For example, try deliberately sticking a parallel fifth into your solution for the week's assignment (after finishing it properly first!) and listen back to it. It will likely "stick out" of the soundscape and feel not at home.  Of course, as Dr. Edwards I think mentioned there are styles of music in which parallel fifths are no problem. That's the whole point: style. A musical style is almost like a collection of archetypal elements or sonic forms that cohere together. In the style of classical diatonic harmony, parallel fifths don't cohere to the overall sonic fingerprint of the style, "sticking out" in an odd manner. That's why, from an artistic perspective, we avoid them in this style. (Only once the style has been mastered, can a composer proceed to break the cookbook's rules in a way which is artistically pleasing and maintains the style.) 
Pavel, I would say it's important to stick to the rules for this one. All the greats broke them though only after they had laboriously learned them!

Title: How do I choose which bass tone?
Post_text:
The choice is usually fairly simple, since there are almost always only two options, and one can usually choose the less "extreme" (in pitch) of the two. If in open structure, I usually chose the option that was lower in pitch to give space for a lower Tenor voice, which spread out the SAT voices appropriately and helped with sonority. If in closed structure I sometimes chose the higher-pitched option, provided there was still space for the appropriate note in the Tenor and voices weren't crossing.
Choosing what octave the bass tone is in is really a matter of preference, just as long as it's the lowest note. The bass gets to operate fairly independently, so it's a matter of your own taste. I'm sure we all had some differences in our choices. 
The guideline I follow for selecting the Bass is to start with the root/note that gives the best sonority and refrain from Â voice crossing.
Another factor could be to choose a bass note that allows for contrary motion, as long as you're not violating other voice leading principles.
It would also depend on the instruments or voices you Â are using. Â Sometimes, you might want the lowest, or octave below, for clarity. Similar or the same instruments, you might want voice the notes close. Â Taking into account of the sound and harmonics of instruments used. Â In my own music, I sometimes move an instrument up/down an octave, to get more clarity in the arrangement.Â 
Throughout the voice leading lectures, the professor was choosing a bass tone for each chord.Â  However, as we went through the examples, I would occasionally choose the bass tone in a different octave than he chose.Â  How does one decide which octave to place the bass tone?
